column1: Will Recep Tayyip Erdoğan cease to be president of Turkey before 15 July 2021?
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']
Not by tomorrow, NO.

Seeing this question for the first time with only 9 days left on the counter- it seems extremely unlikely Erdogan would relinquish power, and no easily accessible information indicates indicates any health problems, mass protest movements or armed opposition resulting from said scandals, etc. Mass arrests in response to the failed coup of 2016 appear to have diminished the military's capacity to interfere in politics.
Nothing on the horizon to indicate a need to change my forecast.
Would be great to be wrong here, but probability is vanishing.
Not going anywhere. Time running out on this question.

He has survived a coup before, and has since cemented his power by cracking down on press freedom and stacking institutions with loyal figures. Highly unlikely he will be forced out any time soon.

But after Armenia/Azerbjian I realize he bas control of the military and a popular victory reinforcing his image. He has cooperation from both Russia and Isreal. Economics, look at how long a strongman can hang on (see Venezula, Belarussia) in bad times. I realze unless he dies of natural causes he ain't going.

You've got to be kidding me. Erdogan is not a wannabe tyrant like Trump, he is an accomplished absolutist quasi sultan. I was just in Istanbul. In case you haven't heard Erdogan reversed Kemal Ataturk who made it a museum in 1934 Erdogan made it a mosque. Erdogan dominates the legislature Erdogan dominates the judiciary. Only Istanbul has elected a non AKP Mayor. Erdogan has the same ideology of the Muslim brotherhood. Indeed he is another brother. Brother or not he Has acquiesced to his son in law buying oil from ISIS and Tehran. He is so powerful he could entrust his Son in law and putative successor with as much as 1 trillion dollars of infrastructure. So now his son in law Head of the Turkish Central Bank Has been fired,. Turkey foreign debt is so huge and the lira so devaluated interest rates will have to be at 20 percent or higher for the foreseeable future. No economist,Erdogan from his childhood in the blue collar pious districts of Istanbul,has wanted to be a modern day Sultan. Just like the Ottomans he intervenes in Libya,Syria, and Turkish oil exploration all over eastern med has almost started a war. Erdogan would have to go stone cold dead before he would leave power. He nay not last as long as Putin but after A decade,no political party,no CHP,Kurd coalition will stop him in elections. The chance of Erdogan dying before end date are 1 to 2 percent. But that would be too convenient for US NATO. Both he and Putin are purely transactional. Putin sells Erdogan S400 anti aircraft systems. Putin and Erdogan fight it out in Libya,Syria and Nagorno-Karabakh between proxies. So if I could I would direct covert support to the Mayor of Istanbul and encourage the development of a political party centered on the cosmopolitan middle class in Istanbul. Turkey has become the 19nth largest economy in world. In the long run Erdogan will fall because the interests of the pious AKP is inconsistent with the interests of the secular middle class and wealthy who benefit from that economy. US should help hasten the process now. US ought to plan for a future where a strong pro Western Democracy will be a true ally in NATO and a real candidate for the EU.

Despite the various controversies, Erdogan is very popular and his tight grip of the media, military and other organs of state mean there is little chance of any election 'going wrong' and him losing his grip on power. However a significant event in Libya, or relating to NATO membership could see him lose some of his grip on the military - but this seems unlikely. Incapacitation, death or a coup are the other options. Given the result of the last coup it would take a brave (or foolish) person to organise, so overall a low probability event.

Politically Erdogan seems safe. As of July 2020 opinion poll, Erdogan received 52% positive view from those polled. This is up from a low of 44% in April. Next presidential election is not scheduled until 2023 and Erogan leads in opinion polls. Erdogan polls between 39%-50%. Potential challengers do not exceed 35%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2023_Turkish_general_election

There are no viable options for Turkish presidency and Erdogan has made sure of that. While an unpleasant fellow, he has working relationships with all substantial middle eastern countries, and serves as a moderating factor (if you can believe that!). His objectives are similar to those of S Arabia and Iran, who are the two big kids duking it out in the region, and can play match-maker. He is highly pragmatic despite his obvious flaws and has the flexibility to survive. While an assassination is possible, these are generally quite rare globally. He is a "both ends against the middle" guy. Not going anywhere soon.

Turkey is deeply involved in this fight and backing Azerbaijan. (The Turkish government also hates the Armenians, due to their historic genocide claims against Turkey. See, I told you this was going to get complicated.) The trouble is Armenia is a member of the Russian-led Collective Security Treat Organisation (CSTO) – a sort of Nato for Eastern Europe – while Turkey is an actual member of Nato. There is a scenario where Azerbaijan’s attack on Armenia triggers the CSTO and Russian forces come to its aid and find themselves fighting Turkish forces which triggers Nato’s article V clause. It’s not that likely, but the possibility only highlights how fraught this military clash is.

The next election is not until 2023 (5 year offices) although there are constant discussions in Turkey of an early election in 2021. Terms for the President and all 600 Parliament members are for five years and while early elections have occurred before, they were months early, not years. According to some political scientists in Turkey, an early election wouldn't happen until August or September '21, but the chances of an early election that soon amidst the pandemic and economic, military, religious and political issues seems very slim. An early election would allow Erdogan to employ a constitutional loop hole that allows him to go beyond the two-term limit with the dissolving of Parliament and would catch the two new opposition parties unprepared and un-consolidated. While the motivation to do this is high, Erdogan needs to ensure that his dwindling support in the nation is enough for an early win.

The constitutional referendum has strengthened his hold and the failed coup has also strengthened his hold over the country however the economic crisis has lost him quite a lot of popularity and the ruling party losing local elections Ankara and Istanbul after 15 years has also to be taken into account(said to be the reason for his decline in popularity).
Turkish economy problems

Erdogan, although not a dictator but is billed a strongman and bully. The opposition to him at home appears to ineffectual at national level. Erdogan has the confidence to straddle a variety of fences. Turkey is a member of NATO and yet the country is purchasing Russian missile systems; he appears to be on good terms with Putin as an ally in both Libya and Syria; he has determined Turkey to be the defender of the Muslim faith and has defended Palestinian rights against the recent Arab agreements to recognise Israel. He is friendly with Trump. Erdogan cannot be compared to previous leaders of modern Turkey and their length of tenure as he used a popular referendum to shift a parliamentary system to an an executive presidency, abolishing the position of Prime minister, diminishing the power of parliament and gaining the ability to rule by decree and appoint ministers and judges and control the budgets of the military and police. Rather than hedging his bets, he appears to confident in expanding the influence of his country and he has achieved internally and is probably in position for the long term. https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/security/reports/2020/08/24/489727/turkeys-president-erdogan-losing-ground-home/ http://www.jamesinturkey.com/can-recep-tayyip-erdogan-run-for-a-third-term-as-president/ https://www.economist.com/europe/2020/09/08/turkeys-strongman-recep-tayyip-erdogan-takes-to-the-world-stage

https://www.npr.org/2020/05/25/861909600/turkish-president-may-call-elections-2-years-prior-the-end-of-his-term-- Great article here from NPR. To be clear, Erdogan has only been president since 2014... and the last two presidents served about 7 years, respectively. But Erdogan started as PM from 2003-14, became President, and in the reforms of 2017, should run for his second term in 2023. The article linked above suggests that Erdogan might try to catch opposition flat footed by a vote in 2021.

Erdogan is a classic strongman dictator, who has jailed or killed all known opposition. Deposing dictators can happen but is extremely difficult from within. He has played US and Russia very well, and know that both need him in power. Further limiting the odds of any outside help in ousting him.

Another round of seems very unlikely. Points for a potential step down would include a new round of hostility popping up in the Middle East, an uprising within Turkey, or unexpected health reasons. Generally though, he doesn't have to seek reelection until 2023, world leaders tend to not step down if they don't have to (that base rate has to be basically 0 for an established leader, except in the case of poor health - Shinzo Abe for example). Erdogan hasn't had a super clear track record in the help department, which brings this up to at least a non-zero chance.
it's only 1% for the time frame, to summarize a position I've stated before, we are in a period of humanity where politicians and leaders do not step down, under any circumstances

The only thing that matters is the economics. Inflation and lira value. The lira is not a free floating currency, it is managed. The pandemic has produced the dollars from tourism that turkey usually gets this stresses the economy. The government and the central bank have tried to keep rates low and push money into the markets and that resulted in a credit boom which makes people happy but can't last forever. Turkey always seems to be one months away from a currency crisis and yet the crisis never seems to happen. There always seems to be storm clouds on Horizon and it never rains. So Erdogan is safe until impending economic collapse. He is to clever to commit and international relations sin that would remove him from office. He uses the international stage to distract from the potential economic calamity that worries him. It also serves to remind Europe and the USA that it is better to have turkey weekend and running around on its own.
